from the contralateral eye, opposite to that on which a particular structure or condition occurs.

recives LGN inputs, found in layer 4. Have receptive fields with on center or off center, surround responses are opposite to center. Receptive field is in shape of bar. Var has specific orientation that is preferred.
are sensitive to edges w/ particular orientation. Can be anywhere in receptive field.
each eye is represented in alternating bands of cells.

sitting here are the sensory neurons = hair cells
have cilia on the top of the cell, looked like someone snipped the hairs at an angle. hair cells do not fire ap. Do not have axons. Synapse with auditory neurons signals are graded changes in Vm.
longest hair cell and the others are called stereocillia. No axons.
what detect sound. 95% of sensory neurons for our ear are these.
more of them. 75% of total hair population. receive input from brain.

column1: high freq motion in the cochlea
column2: causes the basilar membrane to move most at basal end.
move more at apical end
in cochlea, short and stiff respond better to high freq, long flexible to low freq. Also: hairs are constructed to be shorter and stiffer at basal end of cochlea, longer more flexible at apical end

connected to ion channels which are on the tip of the hair. When stereocilia move toward kinocilium, they stretch the tip links and open ion channels, hair cell depolarizes. When stereocilia move opposite direction, (away from kino), tiplinks relax, ion channels close, hair cell hyperpolarizes.
during rarefaction phase of sound 'wave' the stereocilia move toward the kinocilium and the hair cell depolarizes.

column1: when the basilar membrane moves down
column2: during compression of the sound 'wave', stereocilia move away from the kinocilium, ion channel closes, hair cell hyperpolarizes
hair depol, activates v-Ca++ channels which open. Ca++ enters, hair cell releases n.t.

column1: After K+ enters hair top, on basal end of hair cells
column2: this inc [Ca++]in opens Ca++ activated K+ channels. here, K+ exits the cell. This brings Vm back to starting value and then as motion of hair cell moves below starting position, more K+ channels on the hair tips are closed than at rest so Vm hyperpolarizes due to K+ exiting the basal portion of the cell.
The Ca++ activated K+ channels (also called big K channels or bK) when they open, K+ exits, Vm drops

column1: for high freq hair cells (electrial tuning)
column2: gK+ for bK channel is high so K+ exits quickly and Vm can change quiclky.
gK+ for bK channels is much lower and Vm changes more slowly

basilar membrane motion can be tuned down at a particular frequency. This happens if there is a sound that is particularly loud at that frequency. Outer hair cells use prestin motor protein that shortens when Vm+. pulls basilar membrane further up
charged protein that reacts to changes in membrane potential. When Vm becomes (+), prestin shortens. When Vm, becomes -, it lengthens, when it becomes -, it relaxes.
leads to trouble discriminating sounds. Can still hear you, but its hard to make out what you're saying.
from superior olive of brain. inhibitory Ach inhibitory

are tuned to frequency by which hair cells they receive input from, fire a.p. when big stimulus, means lots of spikes. A lesser stimulus or one of freqencies from other hair cells that they do not receive input from, dont fire.
describes auditory neuron's response on graph. Plot threshold on X, freq on y. Minimum response to generate a response as function of frequency of sound.
narrowly tuned
Broadly tuned

by auditory neurons - low freq (100hz or less) auditory neurons will fire AP at same freq as the hair cells release nt. But as freq inc, AP cannot fire fast enough. Instead, fire at the same phase as sound stimulus - can encode frequency higher than AP rate.
Auditory neurons always fire at the same phase of a cycle (fire in the same point in the cycle, generally at the peak). We can use this mechanism up to 4khz
is encoded by the identity of the auditory neuron - which hair cell it gets inputs from auditory neurons ->  Dorsal cochlear nuclei + ventral cochlear nuclei

column1: Direction of the sound stimulus higher freq w/o phase lock (>4khz)
column2: attenuate going from one side of head to other, freq stays the same. In the *superior olive*, neurons have an identity. Right identity epsp from right, ipsp from left.
sound amplitude declines as it passes through your head.

column1: Direction of the sound stimulus for low frequency sounds
column2: where auditory neurons can phase lock, you can use time of arrival of the 2 ears to determine direction. Ears must be far apart for this, done in superior olive of medulla.
Again neurons have identities - "sound from right", "left", or "center",etc. When neuron fires, we know sound came from particular direction.
1. how long sound takes to travel from one side to the other. 2. how long AP take to travel from one side to the other.
losing hair cells - can they be induced to regenerate? research going on - birds can do it.
bypass hair cells entirely, use tonotopic organization of auditory neurons. Wires end at particular frequencies - shorter wire does higher freq.

column1: suppose you want to lift an item
column2: activate a few small mns, get a small contraction. Could do job but if not, bring in more mn units, brings in large mn which cause more fibers to contract. A graded strength to the contraction.

column1: why does the small motorneurons get activated first?
column2: being small, the la afferent synapses are closer to the SIZ so epsps are larger when they reach that place (length constant is effectively larger), its easier for an epsps generated by input from a la afferent to reach threshold in a small mn than a large mn. Less distance for it to travel.
the absolute amount of tension increase will be less than for an already large contraction with addition motor units activated.
gets stretched and stimulated. Surrounded by non-contractile capsule. Has muscle fibers on each end of it (intrafusal fibers). Muscle fibers outside this are extrafusal fibers.
intrafusal do too, restoring tension on the sensor so it can be active if another stretch comes along  at the new shorter muscle length.

pattern can occur without any sensory information. Neural circuitry that produces alternating activity among motorneurons without sensory feedback. Brain synapses with 2 interneurons, each which synapse with motor neuron(one which elevates, one depresses). Interneurons inhibit each other

neuron is hyperpolarized for a while and hyperpolarization is flipped off suddenly, it will fire a burst of action potentials because hyperpolarization allowed more Na+ channels to close and get past the refractory period so more are ready to opem when Vm becomes more positive. Effectively, decreases threshold.
